data.text: Why Do You Bike Tour?
Question: Why do you bike tour? Aside from the "travel" aspect of it, what keeps you coming back year after year?
Cheap,healthy ,rewarding and invigorating lifestyle..
data.author: Craig Martin

data.text: yes ! I had forgotten about the cheap aspect ! I mean, my brother just spent the same amount of money in Italy in a week as I would spend in 10 weeks!
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: exactly.. I tour the world on about $6,000US annually.
data.author: Craig Martin

data.text: Almost free.. Means I hardly have to work.
data.author: Craig Martin

data.text: Bike touring is so engaging with landscapes,wildlife,the people and great for photography,easy to wildcamp,the list goes on
data.author: Craig Martin

data.text: OMG That is like nothing! good for you!!!
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: by the way - your rides are EPIC!

data.text: I sooo want to bike there! HOw was it? How were the accomodations?
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: fab Great beaches all the way south from Colombo and plenty of hills in the centre Plenty of accommodation at all levels Can pay less than £5 for a room and less for food Great people who love tourists
data.author: Keith Roberts

data.text: Challenging
data.author: April Lau

data.text: I have been thinking that such tours are too carbon intensive.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: you mean by car?
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: By plane.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: yes but we make up the difference by traveling by bike!
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: I don't want to argue about the numbers but it's best if people do the research on the carbon load their trips are having. I was just reading how Americans are buying airline tickets like crazy because they want normal life again but the carbon footprint of those flights are going to destroy "normal" life well within their own lifetimes.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: ok i will just keep cycling around my own country. NOT! Americans are not ALL bad! Many of us actually do great things to try to help this planet
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: The average CO2 footprint of an American is 8.4 tons (t for assumed ton) A return flight from JFK to LHR is 1.8 t. What should the average footprint be to stop global warming? 0.6 t. Edit: the numbers need to be confirmed but it is a bit frightening.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: but the average person (not a cyclist) just flies international and domestic at will, then they hire a car, take taxis or go by bus for further travels anyway. The (occasionally) flying cyclist is still doing better for the planet
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: Torture myself !🤣
data.author: Eric Ho TB

data.text: best answer yet!
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: When the road beckons you, one cannot resist.
data.author: Shashank Singh

data.text: A bad leg injury that keeps me from running and the love of travelling
data.author: Allan Christensen

data.text: It's the perfect speed to explore foreign countries for me. Going around 100 kilometres a day really suits me. I typically cycle around 5-6 days, where I take it easy and enjoy my solitude. Then I hit a city or a popular holiday spot for a couple of days and socialise with a few beers and some company from around the world. And then I move on again for another 5-6 of cycling before stopping for another little party. When I was a young backpacker I used to party every day. But the body does not agree with this any longer. Cycling also keeps my weight and my blood pressured own to a level, where I am not too much in danger of dropping dead.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: I'm hooked on the challenge of mental and physical challenge of navigating and surviving in unfamiliar places I'll never see again. The Post Traumatic Stress of surviving trips through the Third World is a plus.
data.author: Eric Knudstrup

data.text: Interesting. PTSD in the literal sense?
data.author: Ingo Tophoven

data.text: I have only ridden in first and second world countries but have backpacked in Central America so I can only imagine what it is like on a bike!
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: Answer : there is not a single reason not to do it. 😁
data.author: John Gero

data.text: Yes, there is.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: it is called facebook, I missed that I admit 😁
data.author: John Gero

data.text: Not sure but I only tour in nice areas….mainly France. I love the scenery, meeting people, riding around a bend and having a chateau, canal, beautiful village, church or any scene really, reveal itself. I love picnics by the canals or long drawn out lunches in some little bistro and lingering over a pitcher of chilled rose. I love birdsong, the rustling of leaves on a tree. I love the steady purr of the chain, the sound of tyres on road. And yes, the pitter patter of raindrops on the tent fly. What is there not to like?
data.author: Garry James

data.text: you obviously have not toured in Sicily in the summer! HELL lol
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: Touring to me is about time and place. Time is considered in terms of season and holiday crowds. I try to avoid temperatures which would make it unpleasant to ride and camp. Can not remember the name of the travel writer who said you can travel in your own town by viewing it in the early morning as it wakes up. Of course I have been caught out by heat wave conditions in Germany and in the south of France, by heaving crowds and few places to pitch a tent while riding towards Vienna, and by unseasonable snow storms in the Dolomites; but I don’t plan for them. Sicily in 2023, earlier in the season but have not started planning.
data.author: Garry James

data.text: I could not agree more about time! This is why I will never again bike around Lake Constance or lake Geneva in July ! Lol
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: also we circumvented Sicily last summer and it was horrific ! I wouldn’t go back to Sicily if someone paid me. Beyond hot, dry, trash everywhere , very crowded, polluted air , beaches were awful - not at all what you may think !
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: Thanks for the info as some friends had been saying how nice it was! Had my doubts and you have confirmed them.
data.author: Garry James

data.text: it is odd that Sicily has a reputation of being this idyllic place. It is like the rest of southern Italy ( they south of Naples): impoverished and VERY dirty. I know - I need to find the beauty in everywhere that I bike - but sometimes it is really impossible 🙂
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text:
We use the bikes to get more attention for our awareness project (we are out to fight Stigma against people with mental health conditions). https://www.cyclingforsociety.org/ And now we just can't think of another way to travel :)
Cyclingforsociety | Stigma free Society
cyclingforsociety.org
data.author: Iris Mueller

data.text: I have some similar initiatives. I would like to talk sometime, just to share thoughts and ideas.
data.author: Ingo Tophoven

data.text: for sure... Let's PM. We are trying to build a network to have bigger impact.
data.author: Iris Mueller

data.text: i like riding bikes. i like travelling. i like over eating.
data.author: Craig Pullen

data.text: OMG. EXACTLY RIGHT 😁
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: Hi Jennie, I occasionally see your name in the most “likely” places! Hope all is going well for you. Do you have any trips planned? We are heading off in September.
data.author: Garry James

data.text: Hey Garry, SNAP! Earlier tonight I also pointed out your comment to my hubbie and saw from your profile that you are riding motor bikes now as well as bicycles. I too have noticed your name pop up in our mutual groups. In June 2021 we had a house fire (we weren't hurt, but lost all 8 bikes in the fire + our car, camping gear, tools, lots of smoke damage through the house. We need a new roof and ceiling, some walls, garage and solar system) and we are gradually replacing the bikes. We are still in temporary accommodation courtesy of the insurance company. This week we finally have touring bikes again as our custom Bike Friday NWT Silks arrived from the US. Very excited. Took them on their first spin today We are planning to go back to NZ for a few weeks cycle touring in February 2022. We can't go away for any length of time while waiting for our house repairs to commence. Where are you going in September?
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: So nice to hear from you but sad to hear the trials and tribulations! Glad material possessions were the only things damaged in the fire but of course, we imbue our possessions with our memories and experiences so often the loss is grievous Have not toured in NZ so am very envious. We are getting our Bike Friday NWT old work horses ready for eight weeks of touring in France. We are riding the La Francette cycle route and then thought we would ride to Tours and do 400 k’s of the Camino Sam Diego to Bordeaux.So happy that we are able to travel OS again. Has not been all calm sailing as I had a bicycle accident ( group ride ) had fractured my sacrum and L3 vertebrae, which put me out of action for quite a while. It will be a bit of a struggle to get back any fitness to prepare for the tour. I see the members of our old touring club out riding. Grown into a large group ! I have always had motorcycles in the background. My Facebook profile picture was, until a week ago, riding my Bike Friday round the seafront of Dieppe. Needed a little street cred in motorcycle world so changed my profile photo a couple of days ago! Are you still working in optometry? I retired at 3.20 pm on the 17 of May, 2019…… not that I am counting.
data.author: Garry James

data.text: Have PM'd you.
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: and the downhills are a lot easier 😉

data.text: spot on. Walking too slow. Car too fast. Bike just right 😃
data.author: James Hubbard

data.text: Keeps me fit, let's me move fast enough to get somewhere but slow enough to see things. Cheap, encourages random sidetrips and serendipitous encounters, allows me to camp in beautiful, remote areas. What's not to like?
data.author: Graydon Hazenberg

data.text: For the climate and now also for peace
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: It allows me to look at the World from the outside.
data.author: Ray Smith

data.text: To lose weight, spend nine months binge eating and three month cycling at the hottest time of year. 😉
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: So many reasons! I find the high highs and low lows addictive. You never know how a day is going to go and in an instant it can go from bad to incredible with the smallest thing. I also love the pace slower than a car but faster than walking and love seeing all the in between places and feeling like you are in the travel because there’s no windscreen you are experiencing all of nature and the weather. But the best thing is it’s strips you down to only the necessities and all you worry about is where to sleep, what to eat and how far to go.
data.author: Amy Collett

data.text: that’s the stuff,
data.author: Douglas Eichhorn

data.text: Well said Amy and its the people you meet on the way .Remember my wife Joan and myself meeting you both in France .We were heading to Denmark you were heading for Turkey .Great way to travel
data.author: Grant McKern

data.text: yes I do remember! Absolutely you meet so many amazing people on tour.

data.text: thanks Amy. I agree with your highs and lows. I love it.

data.text: yes, the pace is the key thing, along with the wider view of the world you pass through.

data.text: OHHHHH this is IT to the T!!! Great synopsis.
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: Different view of the world around us. Enjoying to see things at s relaxed pace. Time and distance not important.
data.author: Abie Koegelenberg

data.text: Pitching your tent on top of a remote hill and alongside the edge of a forest after a long day of cycling. After everything is in place (tent, sleeping bag, pillow, etc) I can finally relax on the grass and enjoy the gorgeous view with a cold nice beer. There's nothing more rewarding than that. Listening to the birds, spotting deer, a fox or even a family of wild boars. Having a chat with my buddy, cooking a nice protein rich meal. There's no money in all the world that can beat those moments.
data.author: Merijn Drenth

data.text: sooooooo agreed!!! I am not rich in money but I have been touring for years and am rich in experience and memories. No money in the world can replace that !
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: Sights, sounds, smells, textures, tastes. Ballistically good health, companionship, curiosity, culture. Living in the moment. Quality time. Distancing myself from routine, distraction, and manipulation.

data.text: ❤️

data.text: love this. !!!!
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: The freedom and simplicity. Seeing a place at 10 miles an hour is magical. And the people you meet are generally wonderful. You have to worry about only a few things. 1. Where am I going today? 2. Where will I stop for lunch? 3. Where am I sleeping tonight? 4. Can I get groceries along the route? That's about it.

data.text: I am inviting my son to see this post. On his first long touring trip, he had the same questions regularly. 🙂

data.text: even 45 years after the first x-country trip, the questions are still the same when I'm on my bike.

data.text: The adventure, being immersed in wonderful places, the quiet, the weather

data.text: The Warmshower host I met along the way. Plus, just being on the road , it's hard to explain. Can't wait to get back on the road. Happy Riding all see you down the road.

data.text: The slower pace, you’re more in touch with your surroundings. Car trips make it too easy to just mash the gas, only stopping for gas and food. The trip becomes more about “making time” then relaxing.

data.text: That feeling of constantly moving forward, and only having to worry about the absoloute basics of things; where to sleep, what to eat, where to pedal to next, what to wear for the day - that and days like these:
data.author: Megan Francesca O'Gorman

data.text: The truth is out there. I am trying to find the optimal balance between spending the rest of my life staying in one place (a home, a house on a piece of property with trees, which I "own" and try to maintain/improve), versus spending time moving around. No question: the best way to move around is by bicycle.
data.author: Rian Mintek

data.text: the great part of travelling is that u can choose the climate u live in and not spend time in miserable cold wet climates.
data.author: Keith Roberts

data.text: misery is in the mind of the beholder. People live in Oregon and on the Olympic Peninsula, because they like it. Gotta have good rain gear.
data.author: Rian Mintek

data.text: Absolute freedom 😎
data.author: Shane Daly

data.text: To see the world at a slower pace!
data.author: Anne Bradley

data.text: Mhm, good question: I wanted to do some social science research around that question. Maybe I can just hear what all others are saying here. 🙂
data.author: Ingo Tophoven

data.text: I bike toured first, because my dad showed me our area (lower Rhine area near Krefeld, Germany) that way and we went on bike tours with my friends. As a teenager, I used bike touring to get away and party and explore Europe. I have always felt it is a good way to see the world, smell and see things more consciously, enjoy times with friends, meet people. Today, as I am 55, I ride my bike and tour for mental health purposes. It slows everything down and makes me feel more connected to nature. But I am not a purist nature lover, as I like my comforts as well, and as my worldview sees nature also as broken and dangerous at times. Yet, it is still the creation we have and it is beautiful. I also connect to God while biking through thinking, singing, and praying. Happy Easter.
data.author: Ingo Tophoven

data.text: nicely put, apart from the god bit, but whatever keeps you going my man.
data.author: Andrew Sutton

data.text: lol i was going to say the same thing about the God thing! But still nicely written ! I think my next question to the group should be how many of us are atheists!🤪
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: I certainly am, I see beauty in nature, I don’t need some all powerful being…..apart from when I’ve made a very silly mistake and find myself struggling up hill with bugger all provisions and it looks like no possibility of finding them, but it soon passes 😎

data.text: We don't own a car, we love sleeping in a tent, it's the best way to see places and meet people.

data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: People tend to like activity that contrasts with their daily life, for Westerners cycle touring offers a lot of contrast: minimalism, close contact with nature and people, some vulnerability (not being protected by a closed vehicle), the 'flow' experience of constant physical activity, the relatively slow pace of movement. Some of these elements one might even see as reflecting deficiencies of western society
data.author: Jorge Witman

data.text: To raise awareness of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder that affects Veterans & First Responders and our community in general.

data.text: Cheap way to travel. Memories last linger. Health. Feeling of accomplishment.
